}}{{TIDTOC|adapter}} ==Overview== These cards were extremely popular in the early 2000s before the 802.11g standard was finalized. :This was the card [[wikipedia:NetStumbler|NetStumbler]] (authored by [http://stumbler.net/ Marius Milner]) was written for.. which started the WarDriving craze of the early 2000s.
This card is not to be confused with... *[[ORiNOCO PC Card (Ruby)|'''Ruby''' ('''Agere''' W4050) radio cards]] (FCC ID IMRWLPCE2411R) **'''Ruby''' cards can only run newer firmware.. which is problematic if you want monitor mode w/ the in-kernel '''orinoco_cs''' *'''HERMES II''' based cards from '''Proxim''' ([[Proxim 8420-WD|8420]] / [[Proxim 8421-WD|8421]]) **these cards are distinguishable by the label art (they feature a businessman) and smaller antenna size **'''HERMES II''' cards use a different driver set than '''HERMES I''' cards *any other '''Proxim''' cards bearing the '''ORiNOCO''' brand
Various files and driver sets for these cards can be found [https://deviwiki.com/files/ORiNOCO here].
==Additional specifications== {{802dot11 RxSens|11b |info=BER < 10^-5 |1M=-94 |2M=-91 |5.5M=-87 |11M=-83 }} :<small>Rx Sensitivity info is per the '''User's Guide''' included with the cards. This page is viewable [http://www.ece.drexel.edu/courses/ECE-S490_TN/WaveLan.pdf here].</small>
==Pictures== === Bronze === See [[Lucent WaveLAN Bronze]]. These cards do not support 802.11b. <center>'''WaveLAN Silver''' <gallery> File:Lucent WaveLAN Silver top.jpg| File:Lucent WaveLAN Silver bot.jpg| </gallery></center> <center>'''ORiNOCO Silver''' <gallery> File:Lucent ORiNOCO Silver top.jpg| File:Lucent ORiNOCO Silver bot.jpg| </gallery></center> <center>'''WaveAccess Gold variant''' <gallery> File:Lucent_WaveAccess_Gold_top.jpg| File:Lucent_WaveAccess_Gold_bot.jpg| </gallery></center> === Early versions (removable shields) === <center>'''Cabletron CSIBD-AA''' <gallery> File:Cabletron CSIBD-AA board top.jpg|top of the board File:Cabletron CSIBD-AA board bot.jpg|bottom of the board </gallery></center> <center>'''User Images''' <gallery> File:Orinoco_top_old.jpg|top of the board File:Orinoco_bottom_old.jpg|bottom of the board </gallery></center> <center>'''Later versions (non-removable shields)''' <gallery> File:Enterasys CSIBD-AA-128 board top.jpg|top of the board File:Enterasys CSIBD-AA-128 board bot.jpg|bottom of the board </gallery></center>[[Has images::external| ]][[Has images::internal| ]][[Has images::label| ]]

===Flashing and PDA modifications===
The cards are a pain to reflash. Flashing via Windows requires a driver compatible with the desired firmware updater and a compatible card identification string (or USB ID) for the firmware updater (barring hex edits to the updater).
If you happen to have one of the Lucent branded [[ORiNOCO USB Client|original USB variants]], you can replace the card inside with different card (most if not all rebranded models should work) and flash it without consequence. This will conveniently allow flashing from within a VMed environment.
Silver models are able to be converted into Gold models by way of ''lincomatic'''s [http://www.lincomatic.com/wireless/software.html Alchemy], allowing you, a lowly civilian, access to military-grade encryption (ROT128). Alchemy also provides the ability to change a number of options in the PDA (MAC address, usable channels, etc). PCMCIA and USB models can use Alchemy.. provided you are using a supported driver set.
For more advanced flashing of the cards (primarily changing the CIS), [https://deviwiki.com/files/Intersil/prism_2/flasher/ Intersil's FLASH.EXE program] is required. :FLASH.EXE requires a genuine DOS environment and a suitable PCMCIA controller to work. :I do not fully remember at the moment <small>and netstumbler.org is currently down</small>, but flashing via this method will probably require conversion into [[wikipedia:SREC_(file_format)|Motorola S-record format]]. :You can easily brick your card with this method. Please exercise caution when flashing with this utility.
[[Category:English Documentation]]
